bestBHT.bht: As members of Christ's Body, we can understand our intimate spiritual union with Him by comparing it to the relationship between man and woman. Just as a woman owes her natural being to the man, so do we owe our entire spiritual being to Christ, our source and head. We are as intimately united to Christ, in a spiritual sense, as if we were literally 'flesh of his flesh, and bone of his bone.' It is through this union that Christ nourishes and cherishes the Church, His mystical body.

Henry Alford: members we are of His Body [,— (being) of His flesh, and of His bones]".
As the woman owed her natural being to the man, her source and head, so we owe our entire spiritual being to Christ, our source and head".
we in our entire spiritual relation, body, soul, and Spirit, are one with Christ, God manifested in our humanity,—parts and members of His glorified Body".
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Because we are members of His body (His literal body), being OF His flesh and of His bones.
Adam's deep sleep, wherein Eve was formed from out of his opened side, is an emblem of Christ's death, which was the birth of the Spouse, the Church.
It is not our bones and flesh, but 'we' that are spiritually propagated (in our soul and spirit now, and in the body hereafter, regenerated) from the manhood of Christ which has flesh and bones.
Albert Barnes: The idea here is, that there is a close and intimate union between the Christian and the Saviour - a union so intimate that they may be spoken of as 'one'.
If we avoid the notion of a 'physical' union, however, it is scarcely possible to use too strong language in describing the union of believers with the Lord Jesus.

There has been manifested on earth nowhere else so strong an attachment as that which binds the Christian to the cross. It is stronger love than that which a man has for his own flesh and bones; for it makes him willing that his flesh should be consumed by fire, or his bones broken on the wheel rather than deny him.
Marvin Vincent: Omit of His flesh and of His bones.
John Calvin: For we are members of his body, of his flesh, and of his bones. First, this is no exaggeration, but the simple truth."
Secondly, he does not simply mean that Christ is a partaker of our nature, but expresses something higher and more emphatic.
Philip Schaff: The thought is quite familiar... here it gives a reason for Christ’s nourishing and cherishing His Church; it is His mystical body, made up of members, ‘integral parts,’ of one organic whole.
This holds good, even if we omit the latter half of the verse... The idea of vital union with Christ is included as well as that of the derivation of our spiritual life from Him.

But the sacramentarian interpretation, which refers it to our partaking of the substance of Christ’s body, fosters materialistic conceptions of the union, and seeks to explain one mystery by propounding another.
Archibald T. Robertson: Of his flesh and of his bones (εκ της σαρκος αυτου κα εκ των οστεων αυτου). These words are in the Textus Receptus (Authorized Version) supported by D G L P cursives Syriac, etc., though wanting in Aleph A B 17 Bohairic."
John Gill: Christ, as man, is of our flesh and of our bones, or a partaker of the same flesh and blood with us; or otherwise, his incarnation would have been of no service to us.

Christ indeed, as God, is the former of all human nature, and, as man, was set up in God's thoughts as the pattern of it; but the apostle is here speaking of the saints, not as men, but as Christians, as new creatures in Christ.

Of his flesh and of his bones: for so the church may be called, his own flesh, his flesh and bones, on account of the marriage relation she stands in to him, and that spiritual union there is between them.
John Wesley: For we — The reason why Christ nourishes and cherishes the church is, that close connexion between them which is here expressed in the words of Moses, originally spoken concerning Eve.
Are members — Are as intimately united to Christ, in a spiritual sense, as if we were literally 'flesh of his flesh, and bone of his bone.'

bhtAttempts.bht: As members of Christ's Body, we can understand our intimate spiritual union with Him by comparing it to the relationship between man and woman. Just as a woman owes her natural being to the man, so do we owe our entire spiritual being to Christ, our source and head. We are not only spiritually propagated from the manhood of Christ, but we are also one with Him, parts and members of His glorified Body. This union is so close and intimate that it can be described as being of His flesh and of His bones. It is through this union that Christ nourishes and cherishes the Church, His mystical body, which is made up of integral parts of one organic whole. This concept of vital union with Christ is a truth that surpasses any physical relationship we could ever experience.

As members of His Body, we owe our entire spiritual being to Christ, our source and head. This intimate union is likened to the relationship between man and woman. Our spiritual relation with Christ makes us one with Him, parts and members of His glorified Body. This union is so close and intimate that it can be described as being of His flesh and of His bones. Through this union, Christ nourishes and cherishes the Church, His mystical body, made up of integral parts of one organic whole.

As parts and members of His glorified Body, our entire spiritual being is owed to Christ, our source and head. Just as a woman owes her natural being to the man, our spiritual relation with Christ makes us one with Him. This close and intimate union is described as being of His flesh and of His bones. It is through this union that Christ nourishes and cherishes the Church, His mystical body, which is made up of integral parts of one organic whole.

As members of Christ's Body, we can understand our intimate spiritual union with Him by comparing it to the relationship between man and woman. Just as a woman owes her natural being to the man, so do we owe our entire spiritual being to Christ, our source and head. We are as intimately united to Christ, in a spiritual sense, as if we were literally 'flesh of his flesh, and bone of his bone.' It is through this union that Christ nourishes and cherishes the Church, His mystical body.
